title: Python is a widely used high-level programming language for general-purpose programming, created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991. Python features a dynamic type system and automatic memory management and supports multiple programming paradigms, including object-oriented, imperative, functional programming, and procedural styles. It has a large and comprehensive standard library.

inline_content.Text: Python is a widely used high-level programming language for general-purpose programming, created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991. Python features a dynamic type system and automatic memory management and supports multiple programming paradigms, including object-oriented, imperative, functional programming, and procedural styles. It has a large and comprehensive standard library.

title: Two major versions of Python are currently in active use:

inline_content.Text: Two major versions of Python are currently in active use:

title: Python 3.x is the current version and is under active development.

inline_content.Text: Python 3.x is the current version and is under active development.

title: Python 2.x is the legacy version and will receive only security updates until 2020. No new features will be implemented. Note that many projects still use Python 2, although migrating to Python 3 is getting easier.

inline_content.Text: Python 2.x is the legacy version and will receive only security updates until 2020. No new features will be implemented. Note that many projects still use Python 2, although migrating to Python 3 is getting easier.

title: You can download and install either version of Python
here
a
https://www.python.org/downloads/

Python 3 vs. Python 2
a

a

title: If you have installed Python 3, but
$ python --version
c
outputs a Python 2 version, you also have Python 2 installed. This is often the case on MacOS, and many Linux distributions. Use
$ python3
c
instead to explicitly use the Python 3 interpreter.

inline_content.Text: If you have installed Python 3, but

instead to explicitly use the Python 3 interpreter.

title: Hello, World in Python using IDLE

inline_content.Text: Hello, World in Python using IDLE

title: IDLE
a
https://docs.python.org/2/library/idle.html
is a simple editor for Python, that comes bundled with Python.

inline_content.Text: is a simple editor for Python, that comes bundled with Python.

title: How to create Hello, World program in IDLE
b

inline_content.Text: How to create Hello, World program in IDLE

title: Open IDLE on your system of choice.

inline_content.Text: Open IDLE on your system of choice.

title:
- In older versions of Windows, it can be found at `All Programs` under the Windows menu.
- In Windows 8+, search for `IDLE` or find it in the apps that are present in your system.
- On Unix-based (including Mac) systems you can open it from the shell by typing `$ idle python_file.py`.

content_resolved.code:
- In older versions of Windows, it can be found at `All Programs` under the Windows menu.
- In Windows 8+, search for `IDLE` or find it in the apps that are present in your system.
- On Unix-based (including Mac) systems you can open it from the shell by typing `$ idle python_file.py`.

title: It will open a shell with options along the top.

inline_content.Text: It will open a shell with options along the top.

title: By executing (running) the
python
c

Python Interpreter
a
https://docs.python.org/3.6/tutorial/interpreter.html
or a REPL (for ‘Read Evaluate Print Loop’).

python3
c

[GCC 6.1.1 20160602] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> print('Hello, World')
Hello, World
>>>

$ python3
Python 3.6.0 (default, Jan 13 2017, 00:00:00) 
[GCC 6.1.1 20160602] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> print('Hello, World')
Hello, World
>>>

title: If you want to cancel a command you’re in the middle of typing and get back to a clean command prompt, while staying inside the Interpreter shell, use CTRL + C.

inline_content.Text: If you want to cancel a command you’re in the middle of typing and get back to a clean command prompt, while staying inside the Interpreter shell, use CTRL + C.

title: Package Management
i
- The PyPA recommended tool for installing Python packages is
PIP
a
https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/
. To install, on your command line execute
pip install <the package name>
c
. For instance,
pip install numpy
c
. (Note: On windows you must add pip to your PATH environment variables. To avoid this, use
python -m pip install <the package name>

title: Shells
i

- So far, we have discussed different ways to run code using Python’s native interactive shell. Shells use Python’s interpretive power for experimenting with code real-time. Alternative shells include
IDLE
a
https://docs.python.org/3/library/idle.html
- a pre-bundled GUI,
IPython
a
https://ipython.org/install.html
- known for extending the interactive experience, etc.

inline_content.Text: - So far, we have discussed different ways to run code using Python’s native interactive shell. Shells use Python’s interpretive power for experimenting with code real-time. Alternative shells include
- known for extending the interactive experience, etc.

title: Programs
i
- For long-term storage you can save content to .py files and edit/execute them as scripts or programs with external tools e.g. shell,
IDEs
a
https://wiki.python.org/moin/IntegratedDevelopmentEnvironments
(such as
PyCharm
a
https://www.jetbrains.com/pycharm/download/
Jupyter notebooks
a
https://github.com/jupyter/notebook
, etc. Intermediate users may use these tools; however, the methods discussed here are sufficient for getting started.

inline_content.Text: - For long-term storage you can save content to .py files and edit/execute them as scripts or programs with external tools e.g. shell,
, etc. Intermediate users may use these tools; however, the methods discussed here are sufficient for getting started.

title: Python tutor
a
http://www.pythontutor.com/visualize.html#mode=edit
allows you to step through Python code so you can visualize how the program will flow, and helps you to understand where your program went wrong.

inline_content.Text: allows you to step through Python code so you can visualize how the program will flow, and helps you to understand where your program went wrong.

title: PEP8
a
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/
defines guidelines for formatting Python code. Formatting code well is important so you can quickly read what the code does.

inline_content.Text: defines guidelines for formatting Python code. Formatting code well is important so you can quickly read what the code does.
